Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Add support for a Usabilla feedback button on every page" (#7768) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
This is behind feature flag `NuGetGallery.UsabillaEveryPage`.

Progress on https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/7385.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/94054/70759998-156d2700-1cfd-11ea-98d6-ed45a3244db8.png)

The survey questions can be changed from the Usabilla portal.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/94054/70760028-3766a980-1cfd-11ea-8729-c97db7a4ffcd.png)

Note that when the modal opens and the page content does not fill the viewport (i.e. there is no vertical scroll bar, the footer jumps up). I have not found a workaround and there is similar behavior on other websites:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/94054/70760084-5ebd7680-1cfd-11ea-85ee-344937f6ab3c.png)

  - [ ] NuGetGallery

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Dependency resolution only within same repository" (#8932) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

NuGet product used:
NuGet.exe

NuGet version:
5.4.0.6315

OS version:
10.0.18363 Build 18363

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

1. Add new source (e.g. **simple-source**) to _nuget.config_

2. Add a new package (e.g. **startup**) to **simple-source**

3. Install the package: `nuget install startup -source simple-source`

NuGet successfully installs **startup**, but then attempts to resolve any dependencies it might have. It seems to do this by searching for the package in simple-source **and** nuget.org. The problem is this: If a different package, on nuget.org, also happens to be named **startup**, nuget.exe will resolve the dependency of that package instead of (in addition to?) mine.

Now, maybe there is a command to tell nuget.exe to only resolve dependencies in a specific repository? Because I like having several sources specified in my nuget.config, but I want to be able to choose between them - not only for the one package, but for all the dependent packages as well.

Even if I enforce unique package id on all packages, maybe some other developer uploads a package to nuget.org that is unique there, but that conflicts with a package on my private feed. So the next time I install that package from my own feed, it would suddenly also download any and all dependency of that new package over at nuget.org

Is this already a feature, that I've missed?

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "How to install dependencies of a referenced project?" (#8895) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

NuGet product used: NuGet.exe

NuGet version: 5.3.1.6268

VS version (if appropriate): 2017

OS version (i.e. win10 v1607 (14393.321)): win10

Worked before? If so, with which NuGet version: No

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem
I have two projects (Project A and Project B) and both have NuGet.config inside the directory where the solution file exists. Project A is dependent on Project B and according to my requirement, I have to reference Project B in Project A under another folder(Components). So I create the following structure to setup Project A:

- **Solution ProjectB**
      - ProjectB
          - Program.cs
          - ProjectB.csproj
          - packages.config
      - NuGet.config

Standalone ProjectB builds and runs fine.

- **Solution ProjectA**
   - ProjectA
        - Program.cs
        - ProjectA.csproj
        - packages.config
   - NuGet.Config
   - ComponentsFolder
        - ProjectB
             - XYZ.cs
             - ProjectB.csproj
             - packages.config
             - NuGet.config 

Now, while trying to build ProjectA it fails because


 all the dependencies for ProjectA is installed, but the dependencies for Project B is not installed. I know this makes sense since the project is created for ProjectA and it will look it's packages.config. 

But, I would like to know if there is any way NuGet will help me install the dependencies for ProjectB from ProjectA, without having to open ProjectB? 

I have attached the zip files of both the projects. Would be awesome if I could get some suggestion.
[ProjectA.zip](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/files/3942503/ProjectA.zip)
[ProjectB.zip](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/files/3942504/ProjectB.zip)

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "The Visual Studio NuGet packages (RestoreManagerPackage and NuGetPackage packages) needs to auto load on solution build events" (#8796) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
See https://dev.azure.com/devdiv/DevDiv/_workitems/edit/792876. 


From a thread: 

We had a discussion on this and decided the proper way to do this is to whitelist the SolutionBuilding UI context for sync autoload. 

After the UI context is whitelisted, nuget will have to add the following into the package definition:
[ProvideAutoLoad(VSConstants.UICONTEXT.SolutionBuilding_string)]

Note that there should be no PackageAutoLoadFlags.BackgroundLoad flag in this registration. Otherwise your package will be async autoloaded, causing the same issue. Note that you may also want to keep the existing autoload on solution exists, as that’s async autoload and helps the Build performance sometimes.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Linux machines failing CI builds due to dotnet-install connection problem" (#8936) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Linux Machines are failing to run Functional Tests when attempting to run dotnet-install.sh.
There appears to be some network configuration or connectivity problem.

Example failing builds:
https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_build/results?buildId=3298450
https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_build/results?buildId=3298446
https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_build/results?buildId=3298399

As a temporary workaround, I placed the resolved script directly into our build folder: https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/8931

[This build](https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DefaultCollection/DevDiv/_build/results?buildId=3317306) calls  curl -o cli/dotnet-install.sh -L -v https://dot.net/v1/dotnet-install.sh.  curl follows a redirection to https://dotnet.microsoft.com/download/dotnet-core/scripts/v1/dotnet-install.sh but is then unable to reach that URL.

@dtivel  noticed that curl tries using the IPv6 address, so he forced IPv4 in [this build](https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DefaultCollection/DevDiv/_build/results?buildId=3317526), but the overall failure is still the same.
